awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  High performance biodegradable sandwich core structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be the development and demonstration of a new manufacturing technology for lightweight bio-based plastics.  Plastic produced from plant materials can have lower environmental impact than petroleum-based plastics, but price and performance issues have limited their adoption. In Phase I, Grow Plastics demonstrated the ability to produce lightweight, low cost, thermally stable 100% bio-based packaging products.  In Phase II, Grow Plastics will continue the development of its products while also working to develop a full-scale manufacturing line. The goal of the technology is to replace billions of pounds of petroleum-based plastic with a lower density plastic requiring half as much material, which is made from plants.

This SBIR Phase II research project proposes to continue the development of a new manufacturing process for layered structures in biomaterials.  Grow Plastics has demonstrated the ability to generate novel, high-performance layered cellular structures in biopolymers in a new manufacturing process using new machinery.  The challenge in Phase II will be to continue the development in materials from Phase I while also scaling the technology to industrial scale.  Materials science and manufacturing techniques will include polymer blending, solid state foaming, and thermal crystallization of polymer blends. Analysis techniques will include tensile testing, differential scanning calorimetry, thermo mechanical analysis, and evaluation of final product properties.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Grow Plastics (now Corumat) is a materials science company driven by our mission to eliminate plastic waste and reduce climate change. This mission is enabled by using our patented materials processing technologies to make compostable, insulating, strong, greaseproof, packaging that contains no known carcinogens at much lower costs than competitive compostable packaging and cost-competitive with conventional packaging.

The principle objective of this research was to de-risk the technology by relocating and running our pilot line in an industrial setting.  This has enabled Corumat to establish operational repeatability, quality standards, and improve automation for commercial rates, and prepare for full-scale production. The work targeted to tune and achieve product performance repeatability, operational repeatability, quality protocols, and shippable products. 

Corumat has demonstrated at the pilot scale the ability to produce reliably food service thermoformed products using our expanded materials that have been well received by a Top 10 fast food chain and other potential customers. We applied for and were approved to pass to Phase II of USDA 9003 Loan Program  using detailed COGS and OPEX models developed during the program.

The technology functions by adding machinery to existing manufacturing facilities and generating a patented, lightweight, crystalline polymer microstructure. The company was fable to demonstrate integration into a USDA Pilot Manufacturing Facilitiy. This convinced a major regional manufacturer to allow Corumat to co-locate and further develop its technology.  The companies have been working collaboratively to fully industrialize the technology.

Product samples have been evaluated in meat packaging machinery, in the test kitchens of a top-10 fast food chain, in bars/restaurants, and have passed third party compost testing.  The materials have passed key Biodegredable Products Institute Tests (BPI) and are undergoing certification, all materials are ASTM D6400 Certified, and the company passed disintegration testing at a major compost test facility.  The products biodegraded into dirt in an estimated 20 days in a commercial compost facility.

The lightweighting technology that enables low-cost, high performance packaging can also be applied to other thermoplastics for additional markets.  The company has had interest in building materials, transportation, and medical applications for its lightweighting technologies.

Corumat's goal is to use its technology to fight climate change and reduce plastic wastes. The company believes that compostable packaging may help divert food waste from landfills, which may generate over 2% of human climate change gases by rotting into methane.  The technology can help reduce plastic waste by replacing traditional plastic packaging with 1/3 the bio-based, compostable materials.

3 patents have been awarded related to the new manufacturing technology, and the unique structures of matter generated. 8 jobs have been created due to NSF support, and tens to hundreds of new jobs may be generated at partner manufacturing facilities in the United States. Many of the competitive compotsable packaging products in the marketplace are imported - this technology may enable more domestic packaging manufacturing jobs.

NSF support and guidance, and partnerships formed with the USDA and Manufacturing partners have allowed the technology to reach pilot scale, and almost reach full commercial scale, very cost effectively. The company is currently seeking additional partners to scale the technology in the US and worldwide.


Last Modified: 12/17/2020
Modified by: Michael A Waggoner
